intro: Antiphytum charruasorum, commonly known as the Charruas' antiphytum, is a rare and unique plant species native to the arid regions of South America. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes parsley and carrots, and is characterized by its distinctive, often hairy foliage. The plant typically grows in rocky soils and is adapted to withstand high temperatures and low water availability. Its flowers are small and clustered, often appearing in umbels, and it produces seeds that are dispersed by wind. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a vulnerable species in its native range.
